commits.message:
Add Metering Detail to Capabilities Response

Every node must independently report metering information while the engine expects an aggregated list of all nodes. The
client expects an encoded `CapabilityResponse` as the payload with exactly one metering report value. These values are
then aggregated for the expected number of response messages and included as metadata in the response forwarded to the
engine. This approach isolates the aggregation logic to a single location in the code.

prs.truncated_body:
When constructing hash from the report to check if operation has been executed previously to support the idempotency behaviour. 2 issues were identified:
- a different ordering of data in map changes the hash generated
- not all type can be used as key for sync.map (must be comparable, eg slices and map are not comparable)

This commit introduces fixes for the above 2 scenarios. Data in map ar

commits.message:
fix(operations): ensure valid hash key and stable ordering

When constructing hash from the report to check if operation has been executed previously to support the idempotency behaviour.
2 issues were identified:
- a different ordering of data in map changes the hash generated
- not all type can be used as key for sync.map (must be comparable, eg slices and map are not comparable)

This commit introduces fixes for the above 2 scenarios.
Data in map are now sorted before converting into hash for comparison.
Key for syncmap are serialsed into string before being used as cache key, string is always a valid cache key.

JIRA: https://smartcontract-it.atlassian.net/browse/CLD-50

Operations reports are read from disk and will be consumed during operation execution during migration. There will be a point where we need to convert the type from Report[any,any] into Report[IN,OUT] due to the type information being known later during the execution.

However, the existing conversion method was incorrect as the type casting is not reliable enough since when json marshalling and

commits.message:
fix(operations): improve report type conversion

Operations reports are read from disk and will be consumed during operation execution during migration.
There will be a point where we need to convert the type from Report[any,any] into Report[IN,OUT] due to the type information being known later during the execution.

However, the existing conversion method was incorrect as the type casting is not reliable enough since when json marshalling and unmarshalling, the type information is lost, struct is converted into maps and int becomes float64.
Eg when marshaling a struct and unmarhalling back it becomes a map[string]interface{}.

This commit addresses this by using json.unmarshal to perform the type conversion instead which is more reliable.

JIRA: https://smartcontract-it.atlassian.net/browse/CLD-50

prs.title: [CLD-50]: fix(operations): make report fully serialiazable
prs.truncated_body:
Currently operations report has 2 fields which are not fully serializable
- Timestamp time.Time
- Err error

`Timestamp` is not serialisable because it has exported fields (potential data lost), however by changing it to pointer, it implements json.marshaler and json.unmarshaler which formats time to RFC 3339.

`Error` is an interface, and error object does not have an exported field so seri

commits.message:
fix(operations): make report fully serialiazable

Currently operations report has 2 fields which are not fully serializable
- Timestamp time.Time
- Err error

`Timestamp` is not serialisable because it has exported fields (potential data lost), however by changing it to pointer, it implements json.marshaler and json.unmarshaler which formats time to RFC 3339.

`Error` is an interface, and error object does not have an exported field so serialising error becomes an empty struct {}. Creating a new error with exported `Message` field allows serialization to write the message to json.

JIRA: https://smartcontract-it.atlassian.net/browse/CLD-50

commits.message:
Added range APIs to smallset, set and set_dynamic and other drive-by cleanups.

By popular demand.  Roughly 1-2 orders of magnitude faster for
operations on large contiguous ranges of elements.

Drive by cleanups:

- util_base.h: FD_FN_PURE/FD_FN_CONST do not hint by default to help
  with various CI and fuzzing tools.  This also eliminates the need for
  maintaining the FD_HAS_HANDHOLDING.

- with-extra-brutality.mk: Hinting is still enabled manually with
  extra-brutality for various linting.

- src/env/env.h: a prototype outside FD_PROTOTYPE pair fixed

- test_pool.c: enabled some checks accidentally disabled due to a typo.

- Also did some minor linting around FD_FN_PURE / FD_FN_CONST in
  util/tmpl.

- And, also by popular demand, did a linting pass on handholding,
  eliminating a handful of checks that aren't actually handhold-y.

prs.title: gui: use string for large ints in json
prs.truncated_body: `JSON.parse` for typical js clients will automatically parse any number as a javascript `number`, which can store numbers smaller than ~2^53 without loosing accuracy. For numbers we expect to be larger than this (i.e. timestamps and lamports), we should explicitly use strings. Application code and convert to `bigint` as needed.

prs.title: fix build by supporting random-1.3
prs.truncated_body:
random-1.3.0 renames `genByteString` into `uniformByteString` and deprecates the former, which causes a warning. Since our CI builds use `-Wall` this causes builds to fail.

This PR fixes the issue by upgrading the build to require `random >=1.3`.

The CI builds (including the frozen build) used outdated minor version of GHC. This PR also updates 9.8.2 to 9.8.4 and 9.6.6. to 9.6.7.

chore(plugin/evm): log libevm version during VM init

See original PR https://github.com/ava-labs/coreth/pull/871

refactor(core/types): separate subnet-evm and upstream identifiers

Reduces overlap between subnet-evm and upstream files:
- Types and variables that are identical to `libevm` are moved to `imports.go`.
- Files that include only `subnet-evm` have the `_ext.go` suffix added.

See original PR https://github.com/ava-labs/coreth/pull/872

chore: remove unused `libevm` directory

These packages are unused and were just copies from the `ava-labs/libevm` repo.

See original PR https://github.com/ava-labs/coreth/pull/876

chore: disallow direct `libevm/params` import

Until a complete transition to a `libevm` package, it shouldn't be allowed to be imported directly.

Remove the package from the allowed list and move a `types` test into `package types_test` to avoid a circular dependency.

See original PR https://github.com/ava-labs/coreth/pull/874

refactor: use upstream `core/types`

Complete the transition of `core/types` to upstream code.

Note that the previous commit results in _all_ upstream types / vars / consts being in the `imports.go` file. This results in a strict partition of upstream and local identifiers so it is safe to simply change import paths.

1. Globally change all imports from `subnet-evm/core/types` to `libevm/core/types`;
2. Rename all `subnet-evm/core/types` imports to `customtypes` for ease of review here;
3. Dot import `libevm/core/types` in tests only to avoid hundreds of noisy changes.

See original PR https://github.com/ava-labs/coreth/pull/875

refactor: move `core/types` to `plugin/evm/types`

The `types` package now only contains `coreth` logic an nothing from upstream so it shouldn't live in the same location in the repo.

Automated:

```shell
$ git mv core/types plugin/evm/types
$ find -name '*.go' | xargs sed -i 's|"github.com/ava-labs/coreth/core/types"|"github.com/ava-labs/coreth/plugin/evm/types"|'
$ golangci-lint run --fix
```

See original PR https://github.com/ava-labs/coreth/pull/877

See original PR https://github.com/ava-labs/coreth/pull/888

- import `NotFound` error from github.com/ava-labs/libevm directly
- Keep our two subnet-evm-specific interfaces at interfaces/interfaces.go

chore(types): move plugin/evm/types to plugin/evm/customtypes

Use libevm/metrics instead of local subnet-evm/metrics.

This is required to be able to continue work on libevm.

(Formerly #1422 which got merged by error, big time apologies for that, and I have no idea how it happened! 🤷 😢  )

Added a "manual test" to visually verify pretty printing log configuration.

### Applica

prs.truncated_body:
**Description**:
The `block_timestamp` in the `BlockHeader` `BlockItem` has replaced `first_transaction_consensus_time`. This updates the consensus node to properly populate the `block_timestamp` and also uses the consensus time of the first round in the block as the block timestamp.

See https://github.com/hiero-ledger/hiero-improvement-proposals/pull/1146

**Related issue(s)**:

Fixes #18

prs.title: fix: replaced elliptic with @noble/curves
prs.truncated_body:
### Description:
This PR resolves a security issue by replacing the elliptic library (which has known vulnerabilities and could leak private keys) with [@noble/curves](https://github.com/paulmillr/noble-curves), a modern, audited, and high-performance alternative for elliptic curve cryptography.

Unlike elliptic, @noble/curves automatically enforces a normalized s value in ECDSA signatures, ali

commits.message:
fix: insecure cryptography

Used maintained and modern cryptography library.
Make sure we return and verify only normalized s value in the ECDSA signature.

prs.title: config: upgrade NeoFS chains protocol configuration
prs.truncated_body:
# Description

We're close to v3.8.0 which means that C# node will be able to process NeoFS chains. We need NeoFS protocol configuration to be up-to-date with the one that is used in real NeoFS mainnet/testnet. Port the https://github.com/nspcc-dev/neo-go/pull/3833.

commits.message:
config: adjust MillisecondsPerBlock for FS networks

We use 1-second blocks in NeoFS mainnet/testnet for quite a long time,
follow https://github.com/nspcc-dev/neo-go/pull/3833.

Signed-off-by: Anna Shaleva <shaleva.ann@nspcc.ru>

ProtocolSettings: fetch MaxValidUntilBlockIncrement from config

It's the protocol setting, hence it needs to be fetched from JSON node
configuration file.
